column2: Who recommends and who decides a dismissal for lack of academic progress?
column3: A department chairperson or a graduate program coordinator, upon the recommendation of the appropriate faculty committee, may recommend dismissal for a student who is failing to make required academic progress in their program. This recommendation shall be forwarded in writing to the associate dean of the Graduate School with a copy to the affected student.

column2: What are the residency requirements for the Ph.D.?
column3: A minimum of three academic years of graduate study is required for the Ph.D. degree. Resident graduate work done at other universities may be counted toward the minimum requirement upon approval of the guidance committee and the Graduate School, but one full academic year must be in residence at the University of New Hampshire.

column2: What is Doctoral Research (999) and when must Ph.D. students register for it?
column3: Ph.D. students at candidacy must register for Doctoral Research (999) each semester during the academic year until the degree is awarded.

column2: When is a Ph.D. student advanced to candidacy and what form is required?
column3: A Ph.D. student is advanced to candidacy for the degree by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the graduate program coordinator after the student has passed the qualifying examination, met the language or proficiency requirements as are deemed desirable by the student's program, declared a topic for dissertation research, and fully formed their doctoral dissertation committee.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=student%20is%20advanced%20to%20candidacy%20for%20the%20degree%20by%20the%20dean%20of%20the%20Graduate%20School%20upon%20recommendation%20of%20the%20graduate%20program%20coordinator%20after%20the%20student)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Candidacy%20Ph.D.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy - Doctoral Committee (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Candidacy%20-%20Doctoral%20Committee%20When%20a%20Ph.D.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy - Qualifying Examination (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Candidacy%20-%20Qualifying%20Examination%20The%20student%27s%20general%20knowledge%20in%20the%20student%27s%20major%20and%20minor%20work%20and%20The%20student%27s%20fitness%20for%20engaging%20in%20research%2C)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy - Qualifying Examination (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Candidacy%20-%20Qualifying%20Examination%20The%20qualifying%20examination%2C%20which%20must%20be%20taken%20at%20UNH%2C%20is%20required%20and%20may%20be%20written%2C%20oral%2C%20or%20both.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy - Qualifying Examination (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: What are the key rules for the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: Students admitted to the accelerated master's program must attend an orientation/advising meeting to accept their offer of admission and maintain a grade­-point average of 3.20 throughout their senior year, complete their undergraduate degree as planned, and pass graduate courses taken for credit with a Grade of B­- or better (some programs have stricter requirements).

column2: What does an AF grade mean?
column3: An "AF" grade, Administrative F, is assigned for failure to either drop or complete a course. An AF grade is considered the same as an "F." Credit/Fail Grades: Given in specific courses having no letter grades, such as thesis/dissertation, as well as other approved courses or seminars.
column4: ["- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Graduate%20Grading%20-%20Grades%20AF%20Grades%3A%20An%20%22AF%22%20grade%2C%20Administrative%20F%2C%20is%20assigned%20for%20failure%20to%20either%20drop%20or%20complete%20a%20course.)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Graduate%20credit%20is%20only%20granted%20for%20courses%20completed%20with%20a%20grade%20of%20B-%C2%AD%20or%20higher.)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=The%20grade%20earned%20will%20replace%20the%20%22IA%22%20once%20the%20work%20has%20been%20completed.)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Failure%20to%20officially%20withdraw%20will%20result%20in%20an%20AF%20grade%2C%20which%20is%20maintained%20on%20the%20official%20student%20record%20and%20included%20in%20the%20grade%20point%20average%20%28GPA%29.)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: When is a CR grade used?
column3: A "CR" grade is assigned for successful completion, while an "F" grade was assigned for failure. Grades Graduate Grading - Grades Letter grades: The following grades are used at the University: A (4.0), A-­ (3.67), B+ (3.33), B (3.0), B-­ (2.67) C+ (2.33), C-­ (1.67). D+ (1.33), D-­ (.67, F (0)).

column2: What does an AU grade mean?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester IA grades will remain on the official transcript.

column2: What does NR mean on a graduate record?
column3: Grades: "NR" indicates "Not Resolved: pending academic integrity allegation".

column2: What is the policy on course withdrawal (W) and its impact?
column3: Students who have been dismissed for failure to make required academic progress may, with the permission of the dean of the Graduate School, enroll as a non-degree student in courses in their program pending a final decision on the appeal.
column4: ["- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Graduate%20Grading%20-%20Grades%20W%20Grades%3A%20If%20a%20student%2C%20for%20compelling%20nonacademic%20reasons%2C%20submits%20an%20approved%20petition%20to%20drop%20a%20course%20during%20the%20withdrawal)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=W%20Grades%3A%20If%20a%20student%2C%20for%20compelling%20nonacademic%20reasons%2C%20submits%20an%20approved%20petition%20to%20drop%20a%20course%20during%20the%20withdrawal%20period%2C%20a%20notation%20of%20%22W%22%20will)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=Academic%20Standards%20-%20Policy%20and%20Procedure%20for%20Program%20Dismissals%20A%20student%20who%20has%20been%20dismissed%20for%20failure%20to%20make%20required%20academic%20progress%20may%2C%20with%20the)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=An%20extension%20will%20be%20granted%20by%20the%20dean%20only%20under%20unusual%20circumstances%20and%20will%20usually%20not%20exceed%20one%20calendar%20year%20from%20the%20end%20of%20the%20semester%20in%20which)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: What happens when a graduate course is repeated?
column3: The most recent grade is included in the cumulative grade-­point average, and only the most recent credit, if any, is added to the cumulative credits earned. A course may only be repeated once.
column4: ["- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Repeated%20courses%3A%20Repeating%20a%20course%20does%20not%20remove%20the%20original%20course%20or%20grade%20from%20the%20record.)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Academic Standards (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=1%20Graduate%20students%20enrolled%20under%20the%20accelerated%20master%27s%20program%20receiving%20any%20grade%20below%20%22B-%C2%AD%22%20in%20a%20graduate%20course%20while%20in%20dual%20status%20may%20be%20dismissed)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Graduate%20Grading%20-%20Grades%20Audit%20Grades%3A%20An%20%22AU%22%20grade%20is%20assigned%20for%20completion%20of%20courses%20for%20which%20an%20audit%20was%20granted.)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Examinations (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Graduate%20Grading%20-%20Examinations%20Examinations%20at%20the%20end%20of%20each%20semester%20may%20be%20given%20in%20any%20course%2C%20but%20all%20such%20examinations%20must%20be%20scheduled%20and%20given%20at)", "- Graduate Courses - Graduate Courses - Simultaneous 700/800 Courses (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/courses/#:~:text=The%20method%20of%20assessing%20graduate%20student%20demonstration%20of%20a%20higher%20level%20of%20understanding%20and%20skill%20is%20made%20clear%20to%20students%20on%20course%20syllabi.)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Examinations (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)", "- Graduate Courses - Graduate Courses - Simultaneous 700/800 Courses (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/courses/)"]

column2: How many times per year are graduate degrees conferred at UNH?
column3: Graduate degrees are conferred three times per year (September 1, December 31, and May) . All students must file an intent-­to-­graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on the UNH Academic Calendar. All degree requirements and coursework must be completed prior to the degree conferral date.

column2: Do I have to file an intent to graduate?
column3: Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. column2: What must be completed before the degree conferral date?
column3: All graduate work for any master's degree must normally be completed within four years from the date of matriculation (enrollment following admission). Students failing to make adequate advancement toward completion of the program are subject to dismissal in advance of the four-year time limit.

column3: The annual commencement ceremony is held in May.

column2: Who can participate in the May commencement ceremony?
column3: Doctoral, Master's, Ed.S., and certificate students who expect to complete their degree program in May are eligible to participate in the May commencement ceremony.

column2: What is an IA grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester IA grades will remain on the official transcript.

column2: Can I do a dual degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Dual%20Degrees%20All%20standard%20policies%20relating%20to%20time%20to%20degree%2C%20residency%20requirements%2C%20academic%20standards%2C%20and%20minimum%20GPA%20required%20to)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Dual%20Degrees%20If%20the%20student%20withdraws%20from%20one%20of%20the%20participating%20programs%2C%20the%20dual-degree%20arrangement%20is%20automatically%20nullified.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Dual%20Degrees%20The%20Graduate%20School%20allows%20UNH%20students%20to%20pursue%20two%20degrees%20at%20UNH%20and%20count%20credits%20toward%20both%20degrees%20under%20the)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Dual%20Degrees%20Accelerated%20Master%27s.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Dual%20Degrees%20Cotutelle%20Ph.D.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: Can I appeal a dismissal?
column3: A student who is dissatisfied with the decision reached by the program chairperson will be notified and after review will notify the student of the decision. If the decision to dismiss stands after informal discussions, a student wishing to enter a formal appeal shall follow the procedure outlined below under “Appeals Process.”
column4: ["- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=Academic%20Standards%20-%20Policy%20and%20Procedure%20for%20Program%20Dismissals%20-%20Appeals%20Process%20To%20appeal%20a%20dismissal%20decision%2C%20a%20student%20must%20submit%20a%20letter%20and%20any)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=If%20the%20decision%20to%20dismiss%20stands%20after%20informal%20discussions%2C%20a%20student%20wishing%20to%20enter%20a%20formal%20appeal%20shall%20follow%20the%20procedure%20outlined%20below%20under)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=The%20appeals%20panel%20will%20then%20make%20a%20final%20determination%20regarding%20whether%20to%20uphold%20or%20overturn%20the%20dismissal%2C%20normally%20within%2020%20days%20of%20receiving%20the%20appeal.)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=Academic%20Standards%20-%20Policy%20and%20Procedure%20for%20Program%20Dismissals%20-%20Appeals%20Process%20Approved%20by%20the%20Graduate%20Council%2C%20April%206%20th%20%2C%202010.)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: How do I reach degree candidacy?
column3: Ph.D. students at candidacy must register for Doctoral Research (999) each semester during the academic year until the degree is awarded. The dean of the Graduate School is an ex-officio member of all doctoral committees.

column2: How long do I have to complete my master’s degree?
column3: The Ph.D. must be completed within four years from the date of matriculation (enrollment following admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field. The DNP, OTD, Ed.S., and Ed.D degrees must be complete within 4 years.

column3: The Graduate Council has mandated that all incoming Ph.D. students complete RCR training approved by the Graduate School by the end of their first semester.

column2: What is a non-terminal degree?
column3: The degree of doctor of education is a terminal doctoral degree that prepares students for careers in educational leadership. The program curriculum comprises courses in educational policy, law, budget management, research methods, and human resources, as well as a research-based capstone. Requirements for completion of the Ed.D.

column2: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?
column3: Students are not eligible to receive credit for any more than the maximum number of thesis credits required by the degree and are expected to monitor their registration to ensure that they do not exceed the maximum.

column2: Where do I file an intent to graduate?
column3: The U.S. Department of Education has a deadline for filing an intent-­to-graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on the UNH Academic Calendar. Students who do not file an intent to graduate will not have their degree awarded.

column2: What is the deadline to file an intent to graduate?
column3: Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. More information on this process is available on the Graduate School’s website. All degree requirements and coursework must be completed prior to the degree conferral date.

column2: What is the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: Accelerated Master's programs offer qualified University of New Hampshire undergraduate students the opportunity to begin graduate coursework in select graduate programs while completing a bachelor's degree.

column2: Can I defer my admission?
column3: Applicants who can't enroll in the term for which admission was offered may request to have their admission deferred for up to one year. Students who request a deferral, and who are not currently active in another degree program, are responsible for dropping any courses they may be currently enrolled in at the time they request the Deferral.

column3: The Graduate School offers single occupancy rooms, each of which includes a mini fridge for your personal use! To discuss all graduate housing options, please contact UNH Housing at Housing.Office@unh.edu.

column2: Does UNH offer student health insurance?
column3: The UNH Student Health Benefits Plan (SHBP) provides comprehensive, student-focused, primary medical care through a team approach. The clinical staff consists of board-certified physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and medical assistants who are committed to prevention and holistic care. Primary medical care is provided for a variety of common concerns.

column3: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master's degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog.

column2: What is full time status?
column3: Students on full assistantships are involved in assistantship activities for 20 hours a week during the academic year. The workload for students on stipend only and hourly appointments is specified at the time of appointment.

column2: How do I withdraw from the program?
column3: Students who withdraw, who have their degree status discontinued, or whose time limit has expired and subsequently desire to resume their academic program, are required to apply for readmission.

column2: Can I change my degree?
column3: The degree of doctor of education is a terminal doctoral degree that prepares students for careers in educational leadership. Requirements for completion of the Ed.D.

column2: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The M.S. in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Acstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: When can students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program begin their capstone experience?
column3: Students in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) are required to enroll in at least one credit under Capstone Experience: BIOT 891 , BIOT 8,92 , or BIOT 8. The capstone (up to 9 credits) will be designed and approved by your faculty advisor or the internship and co-op coordinator and will be consistent with your career development plans.

column2: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students are required to complete the core curriculum courses (chosen based on market analysis and additional industry input) to establish graduate-level skill competencies in the areas of protein biochemistry, molecular biology, and cell biology.

All capstone experiences must be completed by the end of the final examination period of the graduation date for which the degree is to be conferred.

column2: What is the main goal of the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The most appropriate capstone experience(s) for each program is determined by the faculty of each program. Such experiences may include a single integrative course, a performance, an internship or praxis, portfolio, scholarly paper or essay, an examination, research problem, research project, or a thesis.

column2: What does each credit in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program represent in academic work?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) is offered in traditional and accelerated formats, each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Accreditation Certificate program.

column2: What is the main academic focus of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products.

column2: What is the relationship between core courses and elective courses in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The program welcomes you to enroll in courses in other UNH colleges in order to complete your elective requirements. column2: What is the minimum total credit requirement for graduation from the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: A minimum of 90 undergraduate credits must be completed prior to enrolling in graduate (800-level) courses. The capstone (up to 9 credits) will be designed and approved by your faculty advisor or the internship and co-op coordinator and will be consistent with your career development plans.

column2: What is the Accelerated Master’s Option in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Accelerated Option is a graduate degree program designed to provide students with an efficient and cost-effective pathway to earn both a bachelor's and master's degree or graduate certificate, enhancing career opportunities and long-term earning potential.

column2: What are the admission requirements for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) Accelerated Master’s Option?
column3: A minimum 3.2 cumulative GPA is required.* A minimum of 90 undergraduate credits must be completed prior to enrolling in graduate (800-level) courses. Streamlined Graduate School Application (two letters of recommendation; most standardized tests and application fee are waived).

column2: When can eligible students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) Accelerated Option begin taking graduate courses for dual credit?
column3: Students who have been admitted to the program may register for a maximum of 12 credits of 800-­level courses prior to completing their bachelor’s degree. Such courses may, upon recommendation of the department and approval of the Graduate School, count toward both the bachelor's and master's degrees.

column2: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) - The required core curriculum courses consist of Cell Culture, Protein Biochemistry, and Molecular Biology. Typically, students will complete the Core Curriculum courses prior to enrolling in the more advanced offerings.

column2: How will students communicate technical information in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Biotechnology:Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Demonstrate the ability to communicate high-level technical information related to biotechnology in scientific writing and oral presentations to a variety of audiences. Understand, analyze, evaluate, and summarize primary research literature involving biotechnology related topics.

column2: According to the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) description, what three actions will students learn regarding secure information systems?
column3: Security measures include identity management, authentication, access control, data and system security and availability, encryption, integrity mechanisms, system maintenance, and continuity of operations. This course introduces common technological and organizational measures for cybersecurity, with a focus on protection concepts.

column2: Does the IT (M.S.) program require an internship?
column3: Students are required to enroll in at least 1 credit of Internship Experience upon successful completion of nine credits in the program. COMP 891 , COMP 892 , or COMP 893 may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits. Elective courses can be in various disciplines, including computing (COMP), computer science (CS), business and administration (ADMN), analytics and data science (DATA), and more.

column2: What city sponsors are there for the IT (M.S.) program?
column3: The Department of Applied Engineering and Sciences at the Manchester campus offers two master's programs in computing to prepare students for professional careers in IT and Cybersecurity Engineering and for advanced studies in a computing discipline.

column2: What kinds of students does the IT (M.S.) program welcome?
column3: The MS in Information Technology program welcomes students from all over the word. With classes scheduled during the day and in the evening in fall, spring, and summer terms, the program gives students the flexibility to enroll full- or part-time.

column2: How many thesis credits are required in the Information Technology (M.S.) Thesis Option?
column3: Students who are in a thesis program are required to conduct research and prepare a scholarly paper under the guidance of a faculty committee for submission to the Graduate School. The exact number of thesis credits that are required for each degree will be determined by the faculty of the individual programs. Students are not eligible to receive credit for any more than the minimum 30 credits.

column2: What is the goal of the internship experience in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: Students are required to enroll in at least 1 credit of Internship Experience upon successful completion of nine credits in the program. COMP 891 , COMP 892 , or COMP 893 may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits. Elective courses can be in various disciplines, including computing (COMP), computer science (CS), business and administration (ADMN), analytics and data science (DATA), and more.

column2: Can I take 900-level courses as an Accelerated Master’s student for dual credit?
column3: Students who have been admitted to the program may register for a maximum of 12 credits of 800-­level courses prior to completing their bachelor’s degree. Such courses may, upon recommendation of the department and approval of the Graduate School, count toward both the bachelor's and master's degrees. Completion of degree requirements for the two programs need not be at the same time.

column2: Do I need to be admitted to the Accelerated Master’s program to take 800-level courses for dual credit?
column3: Students admitted to the Accelerated Master's program must attend an orientation/advising meeting to accept their offer of admission and maintain a grade­-point average of 3.20 throughout their senior year, complete their undergraduate degree as planned, and pass graduate courses taken for credit with a Grade of B­- or better (some programs have stricter requirements).

column2: What’s the difference between IA and IC grades for graduate students?
column3: Graduate students receiving grades below "B-­" in 9 or more credits , including undergraduate courses taken while a graduate student, will be dismissed from the Graduate School.

column2: Can I appeal a course grade?
column3: A student who has been dismissed for failure to make required academic progress may, with the permission of the dean of the Graduate School, enroll as a non-degree student in courses in their program pending a final decision on the appeal.

column2: What registration is required for graduate assistants to be considered full time?
column3: Students holding appointments must be enrolled as students in order to hold an appointment during the academic year. Assistants, fellows or graduate part-time lecturers must register for a minimum of 6 course/thesis credits, Master's Continuing Research ( GRAD 900 ) or Doctoral Research (999) during each semester in which they hold their appointments.

column2: How many courses can I take during January Term (J-Term)?
column3: Students can register for only one course during January Term, which is a three-week learning opportunity held during winter break.

column2: How is a master’s thesis committee formed at UNH?
column3: A master’s thesis committee is a committee composed of a regular member of the graduate faculty under whose direction it was written and two other members of the graduated faculty nominated by the department chairperson or graduate program coordinator and appointed by the dean of the Graduate School. The committee will normally also serve as the examining committee.

column2: How do I apply for a graduate certificate?
column3: Graduate students must complete at least 4 graduate courses for a minimum of 12 credits of graduate coursework (800- or 900-level courses) organized in a coherent and logical manner to provide knowledge and expertise relevant to a specific aspect of professional and/or personal development.

column2: Can I defer my admission offer?
column3: Applicants who can not enroll in the term for which admission was offered may request to have their admission deferred for up to one year. Students who request a deferral, and who are not currently active in another degree program, are responsible for dropping any courses they may be currently enrolled in at the time they request the Deferral.

column2: How many years do I have to finish my master’s?
column3: The Ph.D. must be completed within eight years of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field. The DNP, OTD, Ed.S., and Ed.D degrees must be complete within 4 years.

column2: Where can I find information about graduate housing?
column3: The Graduate School provides assistance to prospective and current students from the time of their first inquiry about graduate study until completion of their graduate programs, provided the credits are taken in a program other than the one in which the student is seeking the degree and provided such courses are approved by the student's adviser, graduate program coordinator, and the dean of the Graduate School.

column2: How do I submit my thesis?
column3: Students who are in a thesis program are required to conduct research and prepare a scholarly paper under the guidance of a faculty committee for submission to the Graduate School. Guidelines on the purpose, framework, and process for the thesis should be clearly articulated by each program.

column2: What are the mandatory fees for graduate assistants?
column3: Students on full assistantships are charged 50% of the full-time mandatory fees rate. Students appointed as assistants, fellows and lecturers receive a fee waiver for the technology fee during the period of their appointment. Course fees are also covered by the waiver.

column2: How do I apply for financial aid or scholarships?
column3: The university offers a variety of forms of financial assistance to graduate students through the Graduate School and individual departments, most of which are awarded for an academic year commencing in the fall. To be eligible for any assistance, the student must first be admitted to the Graduate school.

column2: How do I withdraw from a graduate program?
column3: A student may request to fully withdraw from their graduate degree program during any semester by obtaining a withdrawal form from the Graduate School website. Students who formally withdraw are required to apply for readmission if they subsequently desire to resume their academic program.

column2: Can I take undergraduate courses as a grad student?
column3: A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/fail basis. Such a petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken. Courses at the 700-­level approved for graduate credit cannot be taken for pass or fail.

column2: What is the time limit for a Ph.D.?
column3: The Ph.D. must be completed within eight years of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field.

column2: What is a non-terminal master’s degree?
column3: The degree of doctor of education is a terminal doctoral degree that prepares students for careers in educational leadership. The program curriculum comprises courses in educational policy, law, budget management, research methods, and human resources, as well as a research-based capstone. Requirements for completion of the Ed.D.

column2: What is the process for appealing an academic dismissal?
column3: A student who has been dismissed for professional, ethical, or academic misconduct may, with the permission of the dean of the Graduate School, enroll as a non-degree student in courses in their program pending a final decision on the appeal.

column2: How many transfer credits can be applied to a graduate degree?
column3: Students can request that a maximum of two courses, for up to 8 credits of graduate level coursework, from an accredited institution authorized to grant graduate degrees, be transferred to count toward their graduate program.

column2: What is a guidance committee?
column3: A guidance committee should be appointed by the program faculty as soon as possible after a student has begun study for the Ph.D. degree. The committee assists the student in outlining a program, preparing for the qualifying examination, and administers the examination.

column2: What is the minimum passing grade for graduate students?
column3: A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/fail basis. Such a petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken. Courses at the 700-­level approved for graduate credit cannot be taken for pass or fail.

column2: Can I enroll in more than one degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.

column2: What is JTerm?
column3: The Master of Science in Project Management (MSLM) is a practice-oriented program ideal for managers who want to enhance their ability to plan and lead complex projects, motivate people, and deliver the desired business value associated with the project.

column3: Continuing Enrollment (GRAD 800) is a program of continuing graduate students who are not enrolled for course credits, thesis credits, Doctoral Research (999) or Master's Continuing Research.

column2: What is GRAD 900?
column3: Continuing graduate students who are not enrolled for course credits, thesis credits, Doctoral Research (999), or GRAD 900 Master's Continuing Research are not in residence, and are not exempt from the continuous enrollment policy, are required to register for GRAD 800 Continuing Enrollment each semester of the academic year (or each summer for students in M.S.T programs).

column2: How do I sibmity my committee?
column3: A doctoral committee will be appointed to supervise and pass on the dissertation and administer the final examination. It shall normally consist of a minimum of five members, usually three from the major department and two from related departments. The dean of the Graduate School is an ex-officio member of all doctoral Committees.

column2: What is the difference between an IA and an IC grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester IA grades will remain on the official transcript.

column3: Graduate students receiving grades below "B--" in 9 or more credits , including undergraduate courses taken while a graduate student, will be dismissed from the Graduate School.

column2: What happens if an accelerated master’s student earns below B- in a graduate course while in dual status?

column2: What must conditionally admitted graduate students do to remain in the Graduate School?
column3: Graduate students admitted on a conditional basis must meet the conditions as stated in the letter of admission in order to remain in the Graduate School.

column2: Can programs set stricter academic standards than the Graduate School?
column3: Students may be dismissed if they accumulate fewer than 9 credits below the "B--" level, and/or fail to make adequate progress in other aspects of their graduate program.

column2: What is the deadline to appeal a dismissal decision?
column3: Generally, dismissed students will not be able to continue in classes pending the outcome of the appeal, but the program chairperson may make a final decision regarding if the student can continue in the program pending an appellate review or continue with conditions.

column2: Who recommends and who decides a dismissal for lack of academic progress?
column3: A department chairperson or a graduate program coordinator, upon the recommendation of the appropriate faculty committee, may recommend dismissal for a student who is failing to make required academic progress in their program. This recommendation shall be forwarded in writing to the associate dean of the Graduate School with a copy to the affected student.

column2: What GPA do graduate students need to be eligible for graduation?
column3: A minimum 3.2 cumulative GPA is required.* A minimum of 90 undergraduate credits must be completed prior to enrolling in graduate (800-level) courses. Streamlined Graduate School Application (two letters of recommendation; most standardized tests and application fee are waived).*

column2: What is the minimum grade for earning graduate credit?
column3: Graduate credit is only granted for courses completed with a grade of B-­ or higher. Individual programs may have stricter requirements, and those are published with their degree program requirements. Graduate credits are earned in courses numbered 800-­999.

column2: How many credits below B- lead to dismissal from the Graduate School?
column3: Graduate students receiving grades below "B--" in 9 or more credits , including undergraduate courses taken while a graduate student, will be dismissed from the Graduate School.

column2: What happens if an accelerated master’s student earns below B- in a graduate course while in dual status?
column3: Graduate students enrolled under the accelerated master's program receiving any grade below "B-­" in a graduate course while in dual status may be dismissed and have their admission to the Graduate School withdrawn.

column2: What is the deadline to appeal a dismissal decision?
column3: Generally, dismissed students will not be able to continue in classes pending the outcome of the appeal, but the program chairperson may make a final decision regarding if the student can continue in the program pending an appellate review or continue with conditions.

column2: Who recommends and who decides a dismissal for lack of academic progress?
column3: A department chairperson or a graduate program coordinator, upon the recommendation of the appropriate faculty committee, may recommend dismissal for a student who is failing to make required academic progress in their program. This recommendation shall be forwarded in writing to the associate dean of the Graduate School with a copy to the affected student.

column2: How many graduate credits are required for a master’s degree at UNH?
column3: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master's degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog.

column2: Is a capstone required for master’s programs?
column3: All master’s degrees at UNH must include a capstone experience, with the exception of capstone courses, must be approved by a committee of at least two faculty members in the student's program and approved by the graduate program coordinator. All capstone experiences must be completed by the end of the final examination period of the graduation date for which the degree is to be conferred.

column2: What are the residency requirements for the Ph.D.?
column3: A minimum of three academic years of graduate study is required for the Ph.D. degree. Resident graduate work done at other universities may be counted toward the minimum requirement upon approval of the guidance committee and the Graduate School, but one full academic year must be in residence at the University of New Hampshire.

column2: What is Doctoral Research (999) and when must Ph.D. students register for it?
column3: Ph.D. students at candidacy must register for Doctoral Research (999) each semester during the academic year until the degree is awarded.

column2: When is a Ph.D. student advanced to candidacy and what form is required?
column3: A Ph.D. student is advanced to candidacy for the degree by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the graduate program coordinator after the student has passed the qualifying examination, met the language or proficiency requirements as are deemed desirable by the student's program, declared a topic for dissertation research, and fully formed their doctoral dissertation committee.

column2: What are the key rules for the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: Students admitted to the accelerated master's program must attend an orientation/advising meeting to accept their offer of admission and maintain a grade­-point average of 3.20 throughout their senior year, complete their undergraduate degree as planned, and pass graduate courses taken for credit with a Grade of B­- or better (some programs have stricter requirements).

column2: What does an AF grade mean?
column3: AF grades are assigned for failure to either drop or complete a course. An "AF" grade is considered the same as an "F." Credit/Fail Grades: Given in specific courses having no letter grades, such as thesis credit, doctoral research, or other continuing courses of more than one semester. The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed.

column2: What is the policy on course withdrawal (W) and its impact?
column3: Students who do not formally withdraw and do not register and pay for course credits, research, or continuing enrollment by the appropriate registration deadline, or do not return from an approved leave of absence, will have their degree status discontinued.

column2: How many times per year are graduate degrees conferred at UNH?
column3: Graduate degrees are conferred three times per year (September 1, December 31, and May) . All students must file an intent-­to-­graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on the UNH Academic Calendar. All degree requirements and coursework must be completed prior to the degree conferral date.

column2: What must be completed before the degree conferral date?
column3: All graduate work for any master's degree must normally be completed within four years from the date of matriculation (enrollment following admission). Students failing to make adequate advancement toward completion of the program are subject to dismissal in advance of the four-year time limit.

column3: The annual commencement ceremony is held in May.

column2: Who can participate in the May commencement ceremony?
column3: Doctoral, Master's, Ed.S., and certificate students who expect to complete their degree program in May are eligible to participate in the May commencement ceremony.

column2: Where can I find the intent-to-graduate deadlines?

column2: What is an IA grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester IA grades will remain on the official transcript.

column2: Can I do a dual degree?
column3: The Dual Degrees Degree Requirements are required to include separate majors within the same degree, or a combination of two different degrees. Students who have been admitted to the program may register for a maximum of 12 credits of 800-­level courses prior to completing their bachelor's degree.

column2: Can I appeal a dismissal?
column3: A student who is dissatisfied with the decision reached by the program chairperson will be notified and after review will notify the student of the decision. If the decision to dismiss stands after informal discussions, a student wishing to enter a formal appeal shall follow the procedure outlined below under “Appeals Process.”
column4: ["- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=Academic%20Standards%20-%20Policy%20and%20Procedure%20for%20Program%20Dismissals%20-%20Appeals%20Process%20To%20appeal%20a%20dismissal%20decision%2C%20a%20student%20must%20submit%20a%20letter%20and%20any)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=If%20the%20decision%20to%20dismiss%20stands%20after%20informal%20discussions%2C%20a%20student%20wishing%20to%20enter%20a%20formal%20appeal%20shall%20follow%20the%20procedure%20outlined%20below%20under)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=The%20appeals%20panel%20will%20then%20make%20a%20final%20determination%20regarding%20whether%20to%20uphold%20or%20overturn%20the%20dismissal%2C%20normally%20within%2020%20days%20of%20receiving%20the%20appeal.)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=Academic%20Standards%20-%20Policy%20and%20Procedure%20for%20Program%20Dismissals%20-%20Appeals%20Process%20Approved%20by%20the%20Graduate%20Council%2C%20April%206%20th%20%2C%202010.)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: How do I reach degree candidacy?
column3: Ph.D. students are advanced to candidacy for the degree by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the graduate program coordinator after the student has passed the qualifying examination, met the language or proficiency requirements as are deemed desirable by the student's program, declared a topic for dissertation research, and fully formed their doctoral dissertation committee.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=students%20at%20candidacy%20must%20register%20for%20Doctoral%20Research%20%28999%29%20each%20semester%20during%20the%20academic%20year%20until%20the%20degree%20is%20awarded.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy - Qualifying Examination (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Ph.D.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=student%20is%20advanced%20to%20candidacy%20for%20the%20degree%20by%20the%20dean%20of%20the%20Graduate%20School%20upon%20recommendation%20of%20the%20graduate%20program%20coordinator%20after%20the%20student)", "- Mathematics Education (Ph.D.) - Mathematics Education (Ph.D.) - Applying (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/mathematics-statistics/mathematics-education-phd/#:~:text=Mathematics%20Education%20%28Ph.D.%29%20-%20Applying%20Students%20are%20advanced%20to%20candidacy%20after%20meeting%20the%20following%20requirements%3A%20Successful%20completion%20of%20written)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy - Qualifying Examination (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)", "- Mathematics Education (Ph.D.) - Mathematics Education (Ph.D.) - Applying (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/mathematics-statistics/mathematics-education-phd/)"]

column2: How long do I have to complete my master’s degree?
column3: Students must complete at least 26 credit hours (seven courses) of graduate-­level coursework in sociology. In addition, students must complete 6-10 credits of Master's Thesis work.

column2: Do I need RCR training?
column3: The Graduate Council has mandated that all incoming Ph.D. students complete RCR training approved by the Graduate School by the end of their first semester.

column2: What is a non-terminal degree?
column3: The degree of doctor of education is a terminal doctoral degree that prepares students for careers in educational leadership. The program curriculum comprises courses in educational policy, law, budget management, research methods, and human resources, as well as a research-based capstone. Requirements for completion of the Ed.D.

column2: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?
column3: Students must complete at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits. The exact number of thesis credits that are required for each degree will be determined by the faculty of the individual programs.

column2: Where do I file an intent to graduate?
column3: The U.S. Department of Education has a deadline for filing an intent-to-graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on the UNH Academic Calendar. Students who do not file an intent to graduate will not have their degree awarded.

column2: What is the deadline to file an intent to graduate?
column3: Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. More information on this process is available on the Graduate School’s website. All degree requirements and coursework must be completed prior to the degree conferral date.

column2: How do I apply to grad school?
column3: The first step toward applying to the program is to contact a faculty member whose research is in a topic that matches your interest in order to arrange support for your thesis or paper of publishable quality. Interested students must submit a full graduate application to the graduate school during their junior year.

column2: Can I take courses without applying?
column3: The admissions committee may offer provisional admission and require that the applicant take certain foundation undergraduate courses prior to beginning the graduate program. Courses may be applied to only one certificate program but may also be applied for a master’s or doctoral degree program at UNH. Students must submit a UNH Transfer Credit Form to request that these courses be applied.

column2: What is the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: Accelerated Master’s programs offer qualified University of New Hampshire undergraduate students the opportunity to begin graduate coursework in select graduate programs while completing a bachelor’s degree.

column2: Can I defer my admission?
column3: Admissions to UNH are made for a specific term and year in one of the following categories: regular or conditional. Applicants who are in the final year of an undergraduate or, in some cases, a graduate degree program are contingent upon the successful completion of that degree program.

column2: Is there housing available?
column3: The Graduate School offers single occupancy rooms, each of which includes a mini fridge for your personal use! To discuss all graduate housing options, please contact UNH Housing at Housing.Office@unh.edu.

column2: Does UNH offer student health insurance?
column3: The UNH Student Health Benefits Plan (SHBP) provides comprehensive, student-focused, primary medical care through a team approach. The clinical staff consists of board-certified physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and medical assistants who are committed to prevention and holistic care. Primary medical care is provided for a variety of common concerns.

column3: Students who wish to pursue a degree program other than the one for which admission was originally granted must complete the appropriate application for a change of degree. column2: How many credits can I take?
column3: Students can take up to 12 credits of the Master's Thesis Sociology (SOC) - SOC 899 - Masters Thesi. Students typically complete 6 credits, however, it can be taken up to 10 credits when permitted by the department by petition. Repeat Rule: May be repeated for a maximum of 10 credits.

column2: What is the difference between GRAD 800 and GRAD 900?
column3: Continuing Enrollment Graduate School (GRAD) - GRAD 800 is for Master's students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. As this grants full-time status, students are also responsible for the full time mandatory fees. Effective Fall 2020, may be taken only once.

column3: Students on full assistantships are involved in assistantship activities for 20 hours a week during the academic year. The workload for students on stipend only and hourly appointments is specified at the time of appointment.

column2: How do I withdraw from the program?

column2: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The M.S. in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Acstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: When can students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program begin their capstone experience?
column3: Students in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) are required to enroll in at least one credit under Capstone Experience: BIOT 891 , BIOT 8.9 , or BIOT 8,89 . The capstone (up to 9 credits) will be designed and approved by your faculty advisor or the internship and co-op coordinator and will be consistent with your career development plans.

column2: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students are required to complete the core curriculum courses (chosen based on market analysis and additional industry input) to establish graduate-level skill competencies in the areas of protein biochemistry, molecular biology, and cell biology.

column2: How many total program credits are composed of core, elective, and capstone work in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone (up to 9 credits) will be designed and approved by your faculty advisor or the internship and co-op coordinator. Capstone C will be a 6 month industry placement at 40 hours per week and earn 9 credits.

column2: Can students begin the capstone before completing 9 credits in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students must attend a mandatory orientation session. Students must submit a special registration form each semester for dual-credit courses and note any DegreeWorks exceptions. column2: What is the maximum number of elective credits in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The M.S. in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program is offered in traditional and accelerated formats, each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: What is the main goal of the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A, a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C, an industry co-op experience.

column2: What is the main academic focus of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

column2: What is the minimum total credit requirement for graduation from the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: A minimum of 90 undergraduate credits must be completed prior to enrolling in graduate (800-level) courses. Streamlined Graduate School Application (two letters of recommendation; most standardized tests and application fee are waived).

column3: A minimum 3.2 cumulative GPA is required.* A minimum of 90 undergraduate credits must be completed prior to enrolling in graduate (800-level) courses. Streamlined Graduate School Application (two letters of recommendation; most standardized tests and application fee are waived).

column2: When can eligible students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) Accelerated Option begin taking graduate courses for dual credit?
column3: The Accelerated Master’s Program is offered in traditional and accelerated formats, each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

column2: How will students communicate technical information in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: A student successfully completing the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Demonstrate the ability to communicate high-level technical information related to biotechnology in scientific writing and oral presentations to a variety of audiences. column2: In the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program, how many hours of academic work does each credit typically represent?
column3: The M.S. in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and  Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column3: Working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. column2: Does the IT (M.S.) program require an internship?

column2: Is there a specific credit requirement for the internship course in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: Students are required to enroll in at least 1 credit of Internship Experience upon successful completion of nine credits in the program. COMP 891 , COMP 892 , or COMP 893 may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits. Elective courses can be in various disciplines, including computing (COMP), computer science (CS), business and administration (ADMN), analytics and data science (DATA), and more.

column3: A minimum 3.2 cumulative GPA is required.* A minimum of 90 undergraduate credits must be completed prior to enrolling in graduate (800-level) courses. Streamlined Graduate School Application (two letters of recommendation; most standardized tests and application fee are waived).*

column2: How many credits can I take for dual credit in the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: The Accelerated Master's program offers a wide range of courses for undergraduate students who have the opportunity to complete a master’s degree or graduate certificate early, and pass graduate courses taken for credit with a grade of B­- or better (some programs have stricter requirements). column2: Do I need to be admitted to the Accelerated Master’s program to take 800-level courses for dual credit?
column3: Students admitted to the accelerated master's program must attend an orientation/advising meeting to accept their offer of admission and maintain a grade­-point average of 3.20 throughout their senior year, complete their undergraduate degree as planned, and pass graduate courses taken for credit with a degree of B­- or better (some programs have stricter requirements).

column2: What’s the difference between IA and IC grades for graduate students?
column3: The IA grade is equivalent to a grade of B-­ or higher. The IC grade is the same as an AF grade, which means that a student entering the program will have a B.S. degree in a technical field such as a mathematics, science, or an engineering discipline.

column2: Can I appeal a course grade?
column3: A student who has been dismissed for failure to make required academic progress may, with the permission of the dean of the Graduate School, enroll as a non-degree student in courses in their program pending a final decision on the appeal.

column2: What registration is required for graduate assistants to be considered full time?
column3: Students holding appointments must be enrolled as students in order to hold an appointment during the academic year. Assistants, fellows or graduate part-time lecturers must register for a minimum of 6 course/thesis credits, Master's Continuing Research ( GRAD 900 ) or Doctoral Research (999) each semester.

column2: How is a master’s thesis committee formed at UNH?
column3: A master's thesis committee is a committee composed of a regular member of the graduate faculty under whose direction it was written and two other members of the graduated faculty nominated by the department chairperson or graduate program coordinator and appointed by the dean of the Graduate School.

column2: How do I apply for a graduate certificate?
column3: The purpose of graduate certificate programs is to serve the needs of both matriculated and non-degree students interested in developing specific skills and knowledge for personal and/or professional development. Graduate certificate programs are credit-based, taught by regular or associate members of the graduate faculty, and normally aligned with existing graduate education curricula.

column2: Can I defer my admission offer?
column3: Admissions are made for a specific term and year in one of the following categories: regular or conditional. Applicants who are in the final year of an undergraduate or, in some cases, a graduate degree program are contingent upon the successful completion of that degree program.

column2: How do I submit my thesis?
column3: Students who are in a thesis program are required to conduct research and prepare a scholarly paper under the guidance of a faculty committee for submission to the Graduate School. Guidelines on the purpose, framework, and process for the thesis should be clearly articulated by each program.

column2: What are the mandatory fees for graduate assistants?
column3: Graduate assistants, fellows and lecturers are charged 50% of the full-time mandatory fees rate. Students appointed as assistants and fellows receive a fee waiver for the technology fee during the period of their appointment. Course fees are also covered by the waiver.

column2: How do I apply for financial aid or scholarships?
column3: Several forms of financial assistance are available to graduate students through the Graduate School and individual departments, most of which are awarded for an academic year commencing in the fall. To be eligible for any assistance, the student must first be admitted to the Graduate school.

column2: How do I withdraw from a graduate program?
column3: Students who are applying for readmission are required to pay an application fee plus, if readmitted, any accumulated continuing enrollment fees for the period during which they have been inactive. Students are not guaranteed readmission and may be evaluated in competition with current applicants to the program.
column4: ["- Registration - Registration - Non-registration - Withdrawal (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/#:~:text=Registration%20-%20Non-registration%20-%20Withdrawal%20A%20student%20may%20request%20to%20fully%20withdraw%20from%20their%20graduate%20degree%20program%20during%20any%20semester%20by%20obtaining%20a)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Graduate%20Grading%20-%20Grades%20NR%20Grades%3A%20%22NR%22%20indicates%20%22Not%20Resolved%3A%20pending%20academic%20integrity%20allegation%22.)", "- Registration - Registration - Non-registration - Readmission (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/#:~:text=Registration%20-%20Non-registration%20-%20Readmission%20Students%20who%20withdraw%2C%20who%20have%20their%20degree%20status%20discontinued%2C%20or%20whose%20time%20limit%20has%20expired%20and)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=If%2C%20after%20consulting%20the%20instructor%2C%20a%20student%20still%20believes%20that%20he%20or%20she%20was%20treated%20unfairly%2C%20he%20or%20she%20has%20the%20right%20to%20seek%20redress%20from%20the%20chairperson)", "- Registration - Registration - Non-registration - Leave of Absence (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/#:~:text=Registration%20-%20Non-registration%20-%20Leave%20of%20Absence%20https%3A//gradschool.unh.edu/student-resources/leave-absence%20Students%20who%2C%20because%20of%20extenuating)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)", "- Registration - Registration - Non-registration - Leave of Absence (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)"]

column2: Can I take undergraduate courses as a grad student?
column3: Graduate courses are offered for graduate credit only and therefore are open only to admitted graduate students or non­-degree students with a minimum of a bachelor’s degree. Advanced undergraduate courses are advanced undergraduate courses.

column2: What is the time limit for a Ph.D.?
column3: The Ph.D. must be completed within eight years of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field.

column2: What is the process for appealing an academic dismissal?
column3: A student who has been dismissed for professional, ethical, or academic misconduct may, with the permission of the dean of the Graduate School, enroll as a non-degree student in courses in their program pending a final decision on the appeal.

column2: How many transfer credits can be applied to a graduate degree?
column3: Students can request that a maximum of two courses, for up to 8 credits of graduate level coursework, from an accredited institution authorized to grant graduate degrees, be transferred to count toward their graduate program.

column2: Can I take a leave of absence?
column3: Students who, because of extenuating circumstances, are unable to pursue their graduate program may request a leave of absence for a maximum of one calendar year. Such circumstances may include medical reasons, military obligation, family emergencies, or hardship.

column2: What is a guidance committee?
column3: A guidance committee should be appointed by the program faculty as soon as possible after a student has begun study for the Ph.D. degree. The committee assists the student in outlining a program, preparing for the qualifying examination, and administers the examination.

column2: Can I take a course Pass/Fail?

column2: How do I change my degree?

column2: Can I appeal a grade?

column2: Can I enroll in more than one degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.

column2: What is GRAD 900?
column3: Grad 900 is for Master's students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. As this grants full-time status, students are also responsible for the full time mandatory fees. Effective Fall 2020, may be taken only once.

column2: How do I sibmity my committee?
column3: During the first semester, the student and advisor jointly select members of a guidance committee. A nomination form must be sent to the graduate school to officially appoint the committee membership. The Dissertation Committee is responsible for administering the dissertation exam.

column2: What is the difference between an IA and an IC grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the grade once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester "IA" grades will remain on the official transcript.
